docs.lead_paragraph: The Dutch financial services company Fortis agreed to buy a dental-benefits division from Protective Life of Birmingham, Ala., for $300 million. The acquisition will make Fortis the fourth-largest provider of dental benefits in the United States, while allowing Protective Life, which recently acquired two insurance companies, to focus on its core life insurance, retirement savings and credit businesses. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Insurance Purchase

docs.lead_paragraph: Blue Cross of California, one of the nation's largest health insurers, announced yesterday that it would pay bonuses to doctors serving its health maintenance organization members based on patient satisfaction and other quality standards. It will also stop paying extra to physicians with the best cost-cutting records. The shift follows a similar move by Harvard Pilgrim Health Care in Boston last month. A number of other managed care companies, including several Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans operated by Anthem Inc., offer rewards for both cutting costs and quality care.

headline.main: In a Shift, an H.M.O. Rewards Doctors for Quality Care

docs.lead_paragraph: A Sacramento Superior Court judge, Lloyd Connelly, ruled that state regulators cannot force California's largest health maintenance organization, Kaiser-Permanente, to pay for Viagra, a decision that could affect prescription coverage at other H.M.O.'s in the state. The ruling allows health plans to exclude sexual dysfunction drugs from prescription benefits. It applies only to Viagra but could affect coverage for other drugs that treat conditions like baldness, where medical necessity is sometimes unclear. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: H.M.O. Coverage For Viagra Is Rejected

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush will call later this week for major changes in Medicare, and as an interim step wants to encourage the elderly to acquire drug discount cards so they can immediately get lower prices at pharmacies, federal officials said today. Such cards are issued by ''buyers' clubs'' organized by private companies that negotiate discounts with drug manufacturers and pharmacies. Administration officials said they were exploring ways to promote the cards' use by quick presidential action, without a need for immediate legislation or federal spending.

headline.main: Bush Drug Plan Calls for Using Discount Cards

docs.abstract: Pres Bush to call for major changes in Medicare, starting with encouraging the elderly to acquire drug discount cards so they can immediately get lower prices at pharmacies; cards are issued by 'buyers' clubs' organized by private companies; Merck says its plan is not substitute for proposed Medicare drug benefits, but does provide discounts of 10 percent to 20 percent; Bush hopes to seize initiative and shape Congressional debate as Senate Finance Committee begins writing Medicare legislation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A major New York health insurer has agreed to reimburse customers $35,000 after failing to pay for emergency room services that should have been covered by their plans, the state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, announced yesterday. Because of a technical error, Group Health Inc. classified 195 emergency room claims as nonemergency treatment, said Ilene Margolin, a company spokeswoman. Customers had to pay those charges themselves, Mr. Spitzer's office said. The company, which processes more than 17 million claims a year for 2.6 million participants, will also pay $1,000 in penalties and $4,000 in costs, Mr. Spitzer said. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Business Briefing | Insurer Corrects Error

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush implored Congress today to pass and send him a patients' bill of rights that addresses his concern for limiting lawsuits, portraying himself as a proponent of -- and not an obstacle to -- legislation that most Americans support. The president said such legislation, which would put new regulations on health insurers and give people in health maintenance organizations more control over their care, was one of his three priorities between now and early August, when Congress begins a monthlong recess.

headline.main: Bush Strikes a Positive Tone On a Patients' Bill of Rights

docs.lead_paragraph: LTV said yesterday that it had reached a labor agreement with the United Steelworkers of America that will help the company, the nation's No. 2 steelmaker, avoid liquidation. Under the tentative agreement, which is to expire in 2006, LTV will lay off 1,300 workers, halt some raises, reduce costs for pension and health benefits and make employees part owners of the company. It clears the way for LTV to seek a $250 million loan under a federal program for ailing steel producers. LTV threatened last month to stop making steel and to eliminate 7,700 jobs if the union did not agree to cost cuts. The union and LTV's creditors came up with an agreement on Friday that the company approved over the weekend. LTV is reorganizing under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law.

headline.main: LTV SAYS IT HAS REACHED AGREEMENT WITH STEELWORKERS

docs.lead_paragraph: In his first six months in office, President Bush has visited 32 states, including four trips to Florida and one to South Dakota, which has fewer people than Staten Island. New York has been nowhere on the presidential map. Today, however, Mr. Bush will at last pay a visit. It will be a quick, low-risk exercise -- he will speak about immigration on Ellis Island and honor the late Cardinal John O'Connor at St. Patrick's Cathedral in a bid to woo particular voting blocs. Nobody expects him to dally. Mr. Bush has been heard to say privately that he cannot stand New York, and if one goes strictly by the numbers, that should come as no surprise. New York preferred Al Gore by a 59-to-35-percent margin. It has five registered Democrats to every three Republicans, and its two Democratic senators are almost certain ''no'' votes on most Bush programs. New York City, which Mr. Bush visited only once during the campaign and whose mayor clearly preferred Senator John McCain's candidacy, is statistically even more hostile. Mr. Bush got 15 percent of the city vote, against Mr. Gore's 77 percent.

headline.main: Welcome to New York, Mr. President

docs.abstract: Editorial, commenting on Pres Bush's first visit to New York since taking office, says even though Bush privately admits he cannot stand New York, which voted overwhelmingly against him in 2000 presidential election, both sides could benefit from closer relationship (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Missing from Paul Krugman's assessment of the budget predicament produced by President Bush's oversize tax cut (column, July 6) is the impact of the impending shortfall on average, struggling Americans. Disproportionately, Americans with disabilities (about one-fifth of the population) are below the poverty line, are not working, lack adequate health insurance and are the first to feel the impact of economic downturns because we tend to rely heavily on government spending to survive.
docs.abstract: American Association of People With Disabilities president Andrew J Imparato letter on Paul Krugman's July 6 column deplores likely negative impact on disabled of budget cuts made necessary by Pres Bush's oversize tax cut
